awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Integrating genetic-morphologic concepts of diversity in ecological and environmental context
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Currently, we have a limited understanding of how diversity is expressed in one of the largest and most critical ecosystems on the planet: marine plankton. This makes it difficult to predict the impacts of climate change and imminent diversity loss on key ecosystem functions that society relies on such as primary production and food web interactions between organisms. In order to understand plankton diversity and its importance, this project will investigate how diversity is expressed in an abundant group of marine protists, the polycystine radiolarians. Research will center on the systematic integration of genetic, morphologic, and ecologic information to improve our knowledge of different scales of radiolarian diversity and its environmental context. To achieve broader participation, the Fellow will mentor undergraduate students at the host institution, and engage the public in locally relevant marine science through outreach programs at the Wrigley Marine Science Center.

Recent surveys of molecular diversity have revealed over an order of magnitude more radiolarian species than morphology-based studies.  Poor harmonization between molecular and morphological taxonomy has made it impossible to pinpoint the reasons for this discrepancy, demanding a reevaluation of classic species concepts and molecular methods.  To address this, the Fellow will investigate relationships and differences between genetic and morphological concepts of diversity. Radiolarian samples will be collected from multiple depths at Station ALOHA (Hawaii) and classified based on skeletal morphology as well as sequencing analysis of the V4 region of the 18S rRNA gene. Patterns of genetic variation paired with observations of physical specimens and their ecological niche information will be used to determine how genetic diversity is expressed both morphologically and ecologically. Environmental and biological metadata available for Station ALOHA will be used to interpret the function of hierarchical levels of radiolarian diversity in environmental context. Research products will include new radiolarian genetic barcodes, which will improve the accuracy of ongoing efforts to monitor global plankton diversity dynamics in a changing climate. The Fellow will undergo training in live plankton sampling and molecular analytical methods, as well as gain vital experience in academic mentoring and outreach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided two years of salary and research support to Dr. Sarah Trubovitz.  The primary goal of this project was to investigate how genetic sequence data is related to morphologically-defined species of a ubiquitous group of marine protistan plankton: the polycystine Radiolaria.  The project was based at the University of Southern California in Dr. Dave Caron’s lab, who is a leader in the field of protistan biology and is among the few experts on living Radiolaria.  Radiolaria are a diverse plankton group that plays integral roles in marine foodwebs and the biological carbon pump, helping to sustain ocean ecosystems and regulate global climate.  It is thus imperative that we understand the biology of this group and can effectively monitor changes in their communities over time. 

New DNA sequencing technology is rapidly advancing our ability to survey the diversity of microbial life and detect community change on a scale that would not have been possible with traditional methods.  However, the relationship between genetic sequence data and morphospecies is not clearly defined for most plankton taxa, including Radiolaria, impeding our ability to interpret the significance of diversity observed in environmental DNA sequence datasets.  To address this problem, Dr. Trubovitz used a combined sequencing and microscopy approach to better understand the genetic diversity of Radiolaria on multiple scales:  individual specimens, morphospecies, and whole communities. 

Samples were collected at sea, approximately 100km north of Oahu, HI in summer 2022.  Individual specimens (solitary cells and colonies) were isolated, and plankton community samples were split for both microscopy and DNA sequencing.  Dr. Trubovitz designed and validated three sets of polymerase chain reaction (PCR) primers to specifically amplify the 18S rRNA gene of each order of polycystine Radiolaria: Collodaria, Nassellaria, and Spumellaria.  DNA from 304 individual specimens and 65 community samples was extracted, amplified, and sent for sequencing.  Individual specimens were morphologically identified from their skeletal remains under transmitted light microscopy (100x-400x magnification), and community sample splits were fully inventoried for morphospecies richness.  Then, DNA sequence data was analyzed to characterize the genetic signatures of individual specimens, morphospecies, and radiolarian communities.

The results of this project showed that polycystine radiolarians have significant intragenomic variability and intraspecies genetic diversity.  96.5% of individual specimens contained multiple amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), typically consisting of one dominant sequence and numerous subdominant sequences.  Groups of specimens belonging to the same morphospecies usually shared some ASVs while other ASVs were only found in a subset of specimens; on occasion, individuals within a morphospecies exhibited different dominant ASVs.  At the community scale, morphospecies and raw sequence diversity were poorly aligned.  Richness of order Nassellaria had a tendency to be underrepresented in sequence data compared to microscopy, whereas Collodaria and Spumellaria tended to yield more sequence variants than morphospecies.  However, these results were contingent on choice of bioinformatic pipeline, with post-clustering approaches showing better agreement with morphospecies than ASVs, operational taxonomic units (OTUs), or Swarm clusters.  Together, these patterns indicate that radiolarians overall have more genetic diversity than morphospecies, and taxonomy-informed interpretation of environmental DNA surveys (metabarcoding) will likely improve insight into the species richness and composition of marine protist communities.  Initial findings from this study were presented at the Ocean Sciences Meeting in February 2024.  Manuscripts detailing these results are currently in preparation for submission to open-access, peer-reviewed scientific journals later this year. 

Beyond scientific results, this award also provided invaluable opportunities for training, professional development, and broadening participation in science.  Dr. Trubovitz, whose background is in micropaleontology, was trained on many aspects of research in the field of marine molecular biology: live plankton sample collection and processing at sea, laboratory procedures for extracting, amplifying, and preparing DNA amplicon libraries for sequencing, bioinformatics, and combined analysis of sequence data with microscopy data.  She also completed a training course at the host institution designed for aspiring faculty, which helped develop skills for effective and inclusive teaching practices in college classrooms.  This award also facilitated cross-disciplinary collaboration and knowledge-sharing at conferences.  Dr. Trubovitz served as the mentor for an undergraduate student’s first research experience in summer 2023, which included training on use of a microscope, taxonomic identification of radiolarians, and data collection protocols.  This award also gave Dr. Trubovitz the chance to help lead an interactive ocean science workshop series for elementary and middle school children at Los Angeles Public Library branches.  The impact of this award therefore included scientific advancement, early-career professional development, and dissemination of knowledge to both scientific communities and the public.
